metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Haihe River Basin (Huailai station-eddy covariance system-10m tower, 2015)
metadata.description:
The data set contains the observation data of the vorticity correlator of 10m tower on December 31, 2015 from January 1, 2015 to solstice.Station is located in huailai county, hebei province, east garden town, under the surface of irrigated corn.The latitude and longitude of the observation point is 115.7880E, 40.3491N, and the altitude is 480m.The acquisition frequency of vortex correlativity instrument is 10Hz, the frame height is 5m, the ultrasonic direction is due to the north, and the distance between the ultrasonic anometer (CSAT3) and the CO2/H2O analyzer (Li7500A) is 15cm.
The released data is the 30-minute data obtained from the post-processing of the original collected 10Hz data with Eddypro software. The main steps of the processing include: outfield value elimination, delay time correction, coordinate rotation (secondary coordinate rotation), frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction and density (WPL) correction.Quality assessment for each intercompared to at the same time, mainly is the atmospheric stability (Δ st) and turbulent characteristics of similarity (ITC) test.The 30min pass value output after processing was also screened :(1) the data when the instrument was wrong was removed;(2) data of 1h before and after precipitation were excluded;(3) the missing rate of 10Hz original data is more than 10% every 30min;(4) the observed data of weak turbulence at night were excluded (u* less than 0.1m/s).The average period of observation data was 30 minutes, 48 data a day, and the missing data was marked as -6999.May 14 solstice May 20 and May 24 solstice June 6 due to power converter damage, data missing.
The observation data released by vortex correlator include:Date/Time for the Date/Time, wind Wdir (°), Wnd horizontal wind speed (m/s), standard deviation Std_Uy lateral wind speed (m/s), ultrasonic virtual temperature Tv (K), the water vapor density H2O (g/m3), carbon dioxide concentration CO2 (mg/m3), friction velocity Ustar) (m/s), the length of cloth hoff, sensible heat flux Hs (W/m2), latent heat flux LE (W/m2), carbon dioxide flux Fc (mg/(m2s)), the quality of the sensible heat flux identifier QA_Hs, the quality of the latent heat flux identifier QA_LE.The quality of the sensible heat and latent heat, carbon dioxide flux identification is divided into three (quality id 0: (Δ st < 30, the ITC < 30);1: (Δ st < 100, ITC < 100);The rest are 2).The meaning of data time, such as 0:30 represents the average between 0:00 and 0:30;The data is stored in *.xls format.
Please refer to Guo et al, 2020 for information of observation test or site, and Liu et al. (2013) for data processing.
metadata.instructions:
File naming method: **** station-####-xx tower, yyyy, where **** represents the site name, #### ## represents the site type, xx represents the tower height (meters), yyyy represents the data observation year.
Data usage: this data is tabular data, which can be opened and viewed by WPS, Ecxel and other software.

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

background: Sensible and latent heat fluxes are important indicators reflecting the intensity of heat and water vapor exchange between the land and atmosphere, influencing the energy balance between them. They provide material, dynamic, and thermal sources for weather systems of different scales and affect the water cycle process between the land and atmosphere. Currently, there are many traditional methods for observing surface fluxes, such as the Eddy-Covariance system (EC), Bowen ratio-energy balance system, and aerodynamic methods. Among these, the Eddy-Covariance system is internationally recognized as the most reliable method for observing surface fluxes; however, its observation scale is relatively small, with spatial representativeness only in the range of tens to hundreds of meters. The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS), compared to traditional Eddy-Covariance systems, can obtain average sensible heat fluxes at a regional scale (hundreds of meters to several kilometers). Since the observation scale of LAS can better match the pixel scale of satellite imagery and the grid scale of numerical weather prediction and climate models, the observations from LAS can serve as ground truth for the pixel/grid scale of remote sensing estimation models, numerical weather prediction models, and climate models, thus optimizing and validating these models. The observation principle of LAS is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST), which, combined with the observed atmospheric refractive index structure parameter C2n and related meteorological data, utilizes the stability universal function fT related to the temperature structure parameter C2T to obtain the regional average sensible heat flux at the surface.
research objective: Using the LAS-related data from Guantao Station (January to December 2009) and Arou Station (January to June and October to November), the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in LAS observations was analyzed, and a quantitative assessment method for the applicability of MOST was explored.
challenges: Due to the influence of underlying surface cover types, flatness, water-heat conditions, and weather conditions, it is difficult to achieve the ideal assumption of uniformity in practice. Currently, domestic research on atmospheric similarity theory mainly focuses on the similarity relationships of wind, temperature profiles, and turbulence variance. However, there is relatively little research on the similarity between temperature structure parameters and turbulence characteristics in the scintillation method.
methods: Before analyzing the applicability of the MOST theory to LAS data, preliminary processing of EC and LAS data is conducted. LAS, EC, and AWS data from the Guantao Station for the year 2009 (January to December) and from the Aru Station (January to June and October to November) are selected.
dataset:
Guantao Station (36°30′54″N, 115°07′39″E) is located in Hezhai Village, Guantao County, Hebei Province. Its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of farmland, including winter wheat, corn, and cotton, with winter wheat and corn being rotated. The growth period for winter wheat is from October to June of the following year, while corn grows from June to October, and cotton grows from May to October, making it a typical farmland underlying surface of the North China Plain. In the LAS source area, winter wheat (corn) accounts for approximately 45% of the area, while cotton accounts for about 47%. 

Arou Station (38°02′40″N, 100°27′53″E) is located in the valley area upstream of the Heihe River, where its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of typical alpine grassland, which is relatively flat. The vegetation in the source area can reach a height of 0.2 to 0.3 meters during the growing season.
findings: (1) Under unstable conditions, large-scale vortex motion, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales can significantly affect the applicability of the MOST theory; (2) Two new methods for determining the applicability of the MOST theory have been established, namely factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, and it has been verified that these two judgment methods are reasonable and reliable.

background: For surface flux measurements, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has become more and more popular in recent years. Compared with traditional observation techniques, it can measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km). At present, LAS observation is not common in China.
research objective: The daily and monthly variation of HLAS is analyzed. And the observation differences between eddy covariance system and LAS, need to be studied further combined with footprint model and energy unbalance of eddy covariance system observation.
challenges: There is much less agreement on the form which universal stability function fT should take. Further more, since the iteration process of HLAS can not be convergence when low wind speed and very stable conditions appearing at night, Wm \ - 5 is specified.
findings: Sensible heat flux (H) calculation with the LAS data of above measurements shows that the beam height of LAS and wind speed are sensitive factors for sensible heat flux measurement (HLAS), zero-plane displacement height is crucial unless the beam height is much larger than it, and Bowen ratio needs to be determined accurately over wet surface, while air temperature, air pressure and aerodynamic roughness length are not sensitive for HLAS. According to the observations mentioned above, LAS can measure surface fluxes both over homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Example.Answer: The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) is an example of a data collection method that measures surface fluxes over a larger scale (500 m to 10 km). It provides regional-scale sensible heat flux measurements and is particularly useful for matching satellite pixel scales, thus serving as a ground truth for remote sensing models.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of challenges faced when using the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in surface flux measurements?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced when using MOST in surface flux measurements is ensuring the applicability of the theory under various surface conditions, such as different types of land cover and weather conditions. Factors like large-scale eddies, atmospheric turbulence, and temperature scales significantly impact the theory's applicability, and new methods like factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods have been developed to assess its use.

Definition.Question: What is the Eddy-Covariance system and how is it used in surface flux measurements?
Definition.Answer: The Eddy-Covariance system (EC) is a widely recognized and reliable method for observing surface fluxes, including heat and moisture exchanges between the land surface and the atmosphere. It involves measuring wind speed, temperature, and gaseous concentrations at high frequencies, typically using instruments like ultrasonic anemometers and gas analyzers. The system captures turbulent fluctuations to calculate fluxes over small spatial scales, usually representing areas ranging from tens to hundreds of meters.

Definition.Question: How does the Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) differ from the Eddy-Covariance system in terms of data collection for surface fluxes?
Definition.Answer: The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) differs from the Eddy-Covariance system by providing surface flux measurements over larger spatial scales, from a few hundred meters to several kilometers. While the EC system is limited to smaller areas due to its high-frequency data collection, the LAS is capable of matching satellite pixel scales and numerical weather prediction model grid scales, making it suitable for regional scale observations. LAS operates based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory and measures the structure parameter of the refractive index of air, which is related to temperature fluctuations.

Definition.Question: What is the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory and why is it important for flux measurements?
Definition.Answer: The Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) is a theoretical framework used to describe the profiles of wind speed, temperature, and humidity in the atmospheric surface layer. It provides a basis for relating these profiles to surface fluxes of momentum, heat, and moisture. MOST is critical for flux measurements as it helps estimate surface fluxes over different surfaces by using dimensionless stability functions and the structure parameters of turbulence, enabling the extrapolation of point measurements to larger scales.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in spatial representation of surface flux measurements between the eddy covariance system and the large aperture scintillometer?
Comparison.Answer: The eddy covariance system measures surface fluxes at a micro-scale, typically representing tens to hundreds of meters, providing detailed but limited spatial coverage. In contrast, the large aperture scintillometer offers a broader spatial representation, ranging from hundreds of meters to several kilometers, which aligns better with the scale of satellite imagery and numerical weather models. This makes LAS more suitable for regional scale observations, whereas the eddy covariance system provides finer details within its smaller observational footprint.

Interpretation.Question: How can the variability in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) across different surfaces be interpreted in terms of the influence of vegetation height and leaf area index (LAI)?
Interpretation.Answer: The variation in z0m across different surfaces can be attributed to the structure and spacing of roughness elements like plants and obstacles on the land surface. The z0m describes the roughness characteristics, and its variability can reflect how these elements influence wind turbulence. By analyzing the directional characteristics of z0m and relating it to factors like vegetation height and LAI, researchers can derive parameterizations useful for surface flux estimations in remote sensing and land surface models.

Interpretation.Question: What do the challenges in applying Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in LAS observations suggest about the complexities of atmospheric stability conditions?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges in applying MOST in LAS observations highlight that real-world conditions often deviate from ideal homogeneous assumptions due to factors like surface cover type, terrain flatness, and weather conditions. The applicability of MOST is affected by large-scale eddy motion, atmospheric turbulence, and temperature scales, especially under unstable conditions. This suggests a need for robust methods to evaluate MOST applicability, such as factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, which can accommodate these complexities.

Interpretation.Question: How might the differences in spatial scales between Eddy-Covariance and LAS systems be interpreted in terms of their applicability for different research needs?
Interpretation.Answer: The differences in spatial scales between Eddy-Covariance and LAS systems can be interpreted as a trade-off between measurement precision and representativeness. Eddy-Covariance systems provide highly accurate flux measurements at a small scale, suitable for detailed local studies. In contrast, LAS systems cover larger areas, aligning better with the scale of satellite pixels and model grid scales, making them suitable for regional studies and validation of remote sensing models. This distinction allows researchers to choose based on the scale and objectives of their study.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in applying the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) for large aperture scintillometer data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in applying MOST for large aperture scintillometer data collection are influenced by surface type, flatness, water-heat conditions, and weather conditions, which make it difficult to achieve the ideal homogeneous assumption. Additionally, the development of atmospheric turbulence and temperature scales under unstable conditions can impact the applicability of MOST.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might data from eddy covariance systems require specific processing steps such as coordinate rotation and density corrections before use?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data from eddy covariance systems require processing steps like coordinate rotation and density corrections to ensure accuracy. These procedures help remove outliers, correct for time delays, and adjust for frequency response and virtual temperature, resulting in more reliable flux measurements by addressing atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity checks.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the limited spatial representativeness of eddy covariance systems, and how might this affect data collection methodologies in diverse landscapes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limited spatial representativeness of eddy covariance systems, typically only a few hundred meters, is caused by the small-scale nature of the measurement footprint. This can affect data collection methodologies in diverse landscapes by necessitating multiple observation points or complementary methods, like large aperture scintillometers, to capture regional-scale flux variations effectively.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using Eddypro software for post-processing raw 10Hz data in terms of data quality and reliability?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using Eddypro software for post-processing raw 10Hz data results in 30-minute data increments with enhanced quality due to steps such as outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, and frequency response correction. This leads to more reliable data for surface flux and meteorological factor observation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of data loss due to equipment malfunction or adverse weather conditions on the completeness and validity of a dataset like the one observed at Huailai Station?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Data loss due to equipment malfunction or adverse weather conditions, as seen with the Huailai Station's power converter issue, results in gaps in the dataset. This affects the completeness of the data, potentially compromising its validity for continuous temporal analysis and comparisons.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of utilizing eddy covariance systems in the collection of surface flux data, and how do these systems contribute to understanding energy and water vapor exchange processes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of utilizing eddy covariance systems in the collection of surface flux data is to provide reliable and accurate measurements of fluxes such as sensible heat and latent heat between the land surface and the atmosphere. These systems contribute to understanding energy and water vapor exchange processes by offering insights into the energy balance and water cycle at various scales, which are critical for different weather systems.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of using Large Aperture Scintillometers (LAS) in conjunction with eddy covariance data to assess the applicability of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, and what specific insights do LAS provide at regional scales?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of using Large Aperture Scintillometers (LAS) with eddy covariance data is to evaluate the applicability of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, particularly in relation to the measurement of sensible heat fluxes over larger spatial scales. LAS provides valuable insights at regional scales by capturing average sensible heat flux over several hundred meters to kilometers, which aligns more closely with the scales used in satellite remote sensing and numerical weather prediction models.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in processing raw data from a 10Hz eddy covariance system to obtain 30-minute averaged surface flux measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The raw data from the 10Hz eddy covariance system is processed using Eddypro software. The main steps include the removal of outliers, delay time correction, coordinate rotation (double rotation), frequency response correction, sonic temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Flux values undergo quality assessment based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. Additionally, data is filtered by removing erroneous data, excluding data around precipitation events, and omitting data with a high percentage of missing original measurements. Observations with weak nighttime turbulence are also excluded.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) assessed in the context of large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data collection?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The applicability of MOST in LAS data collection is assessed by analyzing the stability conditions, the development of atmospheric turbulence, and temperature scales. Two new methods for evaluating the applicability are established: the factor analysis method and the temperature structure parameter method. These methods are validated as reasonable and reliable for assessing MOST applicability under practical conditions influenced by surface cover types, flatness, and weather conditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key factors considered when comparing surface flux measurements between eddy covariance systems and large aperture scintillometers?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Key factors considered include the beam height of the LAS, wind speed, and zero-plane displacement height. The Bowen ratio needs to be accurately determined over wet surfaces, while factors like air temperature, air pressure, and aerodynamic roughness length are less sensitive for LAS measurements. The comparison also involves analyzing the energy balance of eddy covariance system observations and utilizing footprint models to understand observation differences.

Enablement.Question: How can the integration of eddy covariance systems and large aperture scintillometers enhance the accuracy of surface flux measurements in various environmental conditions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration allows for analyzing differences in observations between the two systems, using footprint models to address energy unbalance issues, and understanding the sensitivity of factors like beam height and wind speed, which are crucial for accurate sensible heat flux measurements.

Expectation.Question: Why is it difficult to apply Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) universally in the analysis of large aperture scintillometer data?
Expectation.Answer: MOST theory assumes homogeneity in land surface properties, but in reality, conditions such as land cover type, topography, and atmospheric stability can affect its applicability. The challenges arise from the difficulty in meeting these idealized assumptions under real-world conditions, leading to the need for tailored applicability judgment methods.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional eddy covariance systems face limitations in representing regional-scale surface flux observations?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional eddy covariance systems are recognized for their reliability in surface flux observations, but their spatial representativeness is limited to only tens to hundreds of meters. This makes it challenging to capture regional-scale flux variations, which are better addressed by systems like large aperture scintillometers that can cover larger areas more representative of satellite pixel or model grid scales.

Judgmental.Question: What are the perceived challenges in ensuring data quality and reliability when processing flux data from eddy covariance systems?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in ensuring data quality from eddy covariance systems include managing the effects of equipment errors, removing data influenced by precipitation, and addressing issues related to low turbulence at night. The rigorous post-processing steps like coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and quality assessment are crucial to maintaining data reliability.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how might the integration of remote sensing models enhance the parameterization of aerodynamic roughness length for regional flux estimations?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating remote sensing models can enhance the parameterization of aerodynamic roughness length by providing broader spatial coverage and capturing variations in surface properties like vegetation height and leaf area index. This integration can help refine local and regional scale estimations, making them more representative of the actual surface conditions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the aerodynamic roughness length can be calculated accurately across different land surfaces using remote sensing techniques.
Assertion.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is typically calculated using wind profile measurements based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory. In remote sensing, parameterizations relating z0m to land surface properties, such as vegetation height and leaf area index, are used. This approach takes into account the structure and spacing of roughness elements on the surface.

Its measurements are better aligned with the pixel scale of satellite data and the grid scale of numerical weather prediction and climate models, providing a more accurate representation for these larger scales.

Assertion.Answer: Eddy covariance systems measure surface fluxes at smaller spatial scales, while large aperture scintillometers cover larger areas. By combining data from both methods and using a footprint model, researchers can analyze differences and validate model accuracy. The comparison helps in understanding the scale-dependent nature of surface flux measurements and addressing energy balance issues in eddy covariance observations.

Request/Directive.Answer: In the field of eddy covariance system datasets, data processing typically involves steps such as outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction. Quality assessment often focuses on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics.
